feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system feature that automatically computes and deducts daily pay rates for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates daily pay by dividing the employee's total salary (basic plus allowances) by the number of actual working or calendar days in the month, accounting for public holidays. The feature generates automatic pay deductions that are reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests. This ensures accurate salary reductions based on the organization's leave policy (working days or calendar days). The calculator is essential for maintaining payroll accuracy and compliance with leave management policies.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article documents how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It explains that daily pay is derived by dividing the total salary (basic + allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month. The article clarifies that organizations may follow either a calendar days policy (e.g., 30 days) or a working days policy (e.g., 22 days), and that public holidays must be deducted from the working days total to determine actual working days. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature, explaining its purpose as a flexible alternative to legacy wage calculation methods. Describes three calculation base options (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, allowances only), and its impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Provides access path (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation) and notes regional labor law compliance for UAE and KSA companies using 30-day calculation cycles.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Changes affect all active payroll amounts and require transaction rejection if the payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions. The feature impacts both first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations.

Provide a flexible and customizable method for calculating daily wages to determine salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction amounts with greater control than previously available.

To adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days).

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request is approved and a corresponding salary deduction must be calculated and applied to the employee's payroll.
steps: Receive and approve the unpaid leave request
Identify the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days)
Determine the total number of days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the calculation month
Deduct public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days
Retrieve the employee's total salary amount (basic + allowance)
Apply the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days
Automatically generate and reflect the pay deduction on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for payroll processing, including salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.
steps: Navigate to Settings menu
Select Payroll option
Choose Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include: basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only
Apply configuration

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked (applicable for new hires or departing employees)
steps: Navigate to Settings menu
Select Payroll option
Choose Daily wage calculation
Select calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
Save changes
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated using the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of Actual Working Days in the Month. ; The number of days used in the calculation depends on the organization's leave policy: either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days). ; Public holidays falling within the month must be deducted from the working days total to determine the actual working days used in the daily pay calculation. ; Daily pay calculations are only performed upon approval of an unpaid leave request; the deduction is automatically created and reflected on the payroll table.

Calculation base options are limited to three types: calendar days (actual days in month), working days (excluding weekends and public holidays), or custom days (company-defined). ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days as the calculation base to align with regional labor law requirements. ; Salary component selection is limited to three options: basic salary only, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only.

Changes to salary proration will immediately affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must reject the existing transactions before saving new salary proration changes.

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: Public holidays must be carefully identified and subtracted from the working days total; failure to account for public holidays will result in incorrect daily pay calculations. For example, if 2 days are public holidays in a 22-working-day month, the calculation must use 20 days, not 22 days. ; The leave policy type (calendar days vs. working days) significantly impacts the daily pay calculation and must be correctly identified before performing the calculation.

Calendar days calculation varies by month length (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February), which impacts daily wage calculations and resulting proration amounts. ; Different calculation bases (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) produce different daily wage rates and can significantly impact final wage calculations for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions and then save the changes for salary proration to take effect.

feature_interactions_dependencies.interaction: The daily wage calculator integrates with the leave management system to receive approved unpaid leave requests and with the payroll system to automatically create and reflect pay deductions on the payroll table. ; The feature depends on employee records to retrieve salary information (basic + allowance) and on the organization's leave policy configuration to determine the calculation basis (calendar or working days).

Daily Wage Calculator impacts three main payroll areas: Salary proration, Leave encashment, and Unpaid leave deduction calculations. ; Feature depends on company's public holiday calendar configuration to accurately calculate working days when that calculation base is selected.
Daily Wage Calculator interacts with the Payroll system and directly impacts active payroll table transactions, first salary calculations, and end-of-service settlement amounts.
